instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> high voltage 13.4V
threads.message: [LEFT]hey guys, I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (which im using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board schematics and boardview), board had minor liquid spill around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and damaged capacitors (<CAPACITOR>C7680</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7660</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7653</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7650</CAPACITOR>), and also found <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground, after injecting power <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> was causing the short, replaced it, short is gone, but as of now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is high, at 13.4Vm any ideas what could be causing PPBUS to be high,[/LEFT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> high voltage 13.4V
threads.message:
13V is correct voltage; your DMM can show more if has low battery.
Did you check it on F7000?
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present?
